content.raw: It fails for me sporadically with any of the physics engines. I think it's a race condition that they don't have enough time to load the plugins, which only happens during the first world step
content.html: It fails for me sporadically with any of the physics engines. I think it's a race condition that they don't have enough time to load the plugins, which only happens during the first world step

This improves it, but I still see failures sometimes.

diff -r 2ff9d8f95860 test/integration/world_open.cc
--- a/test/integration/world_open.cc    Thu Jan 28 15:32:10 2016 -0800
+++ b/test/integration/world_open.cc    Fri Jan 29 00:12:10 2016 -0800
@@ -179,6 +179,7 @@
     // Get the new world
     world = physics::get_world("default");
     ASSERT_TRUE(world != NULL);
+    world->Step(100);

     // Check models
     size_t count = 0;

content.raw: I've been debugging this and I think I finally have a clue. The `SensorManager` never knows about a world being deleted so new worlds without sensors might not get `SensorsInitialized`.
content.html: I've been debugging this and I think I finally have a clue. The SensorManager never knows about a world being deleted so new worlds without sensors might not get SensorsInitialized.

content.raw:
I checked that the file is properly logged up to the point when the world is destroyed. I guess that's the expected behaviour, right? I tried this:

1. Start `gzserver` recording a log of a world with movement:

    `gzserver -r --record_path ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/ ../worlds/random_velocity.world --verbose `

2. Give it some time to record something

3. Open a new world that has moving stuff:

    `./pub_open_world ~/gazebo_source/gazebo/worlds/underwater.world`

4. Give it some time so we know the other world has been loaded and there are things moving and all. 

5. Then close `gzserver`.

6. Now playback the file and check we logged the first world:

    `gazebo --verbose -p ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/state.log -u`
content.html:
I checked that the file is properly logged up to the point when the world is destroyed. I guess that's the expected behaviour, right? I tried this:

  1. Start gzserver recording a log of a world with movement:

    gzserver -r --record_path ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/ ../worlds/random_velocity.world --verbose

  2. Give it some time to record something

  3. Open a new world that has moving stuff:

    ./pub_open_world ~/gazebo_source/gazebo/worlds/underwater.world

  4. Give it some time so we know the other world has been loaded and there are things moving and all.

  5. Then close gzserver.

  6. Now playback the file and check we logged the first world:

    gazebo --verbose -p ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/state.log -u

content.raw: Just curiosity, not a feature request. Is in the plan to be able to have more than one world running in parallel within a single server?
content.html: Just curiosity, not a feature request. Is in the plan to be able to have more than one world running in parallel within a single server?

content.raw: I've seen there's some logic in the server to keep several worlds opened at once. But I'm not sure what's the intended use and how it would play in this context.
content.html: I've seen there's some logic in the server to keep several worlds opened at once. But I'm not sure what's the intended use and how it would play in this context.

content.raw:
I've been testing the pr2.world:

1. `gazebo worlds/pr2.world --verbose` 

and repeatedly doing:

1. `./pub_open_world worlds/pr2.world` in a separate terminal

the first time the pr2.world is opened I see two laser scan topics:

~~~
$ gz topic -l | grep scan
/gazebo/default/pr2/base_footprint/base_laser/scan
/gazebo/default/pr2/laser_tilt_mount_link/laser_tilt/scan
~~~

once I execute `pub_open_world`, one topic is lost

~~~
$ gz topic -l | grep scan
/gazebo/default/pr2/base_footprint/base_laser/scan
~~~

and ocassionally I get a crash on the first `pub_open_world` cmd (if it works the first time then it's likely to work again):

~~~
[Msg] Opening world file [worlds/pr2.world]
[Err] [ODEMultiRayShape.cc:73] EXCEPTION: Invalid physics engine. Must use ODE.

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'gazebo::common::Exception'
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:605] ConnectionManager is not initialized
~~~
content.html:
I've been testing the pr2.world:

  1. gazebo worlds/pr2.world --verbose

and repeatedly doing:

  1. ./pub_open_world worlds/pr2.world in a separate terminal

the first time the pr2.world is opened I see two laser scan topics:

$ gz topic -l | grep scan
/gazebo/default/pr2/base_footprint/base_laser/scan
/gazebo/default/pr2/laser_tilt_mount_link/laser_tilt/scan

once I execute pub_open_world, one topic is lost

$ gz topic -l | grep scan
/gazebo/default/pr2/base_footprint/base_laser/scan

and ocassionally I get a crash on the first pub_open_world cmd (if it works the first time then it's likely to work again):

[Msg] Opening world file [worlds/pr2.world]
[Err] [ODEMultiRayShape.cc:73] EXCEPTION: Invalid physics engine. Must use ODE.

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'gazebo::common::Exception'
[Err] [ConnectionManager.cc:605] ConnectionManager is not initialized

content.raw:
issues with sensors may be related to the `PluginCount` test failure mentioned above, since sensors must be initialized before plugins can be loaded:

* [World.cc:619](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/7c23991510420e25940bee2c5566b083dc715ed3/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-619)
content.html:
issues with sensors may be related to the PluginCount test failure mentioned above, since sensors must be initialized before plugins can be loaded:

  • World.cc:619

content.raw: ok I checked there's definitely a problem loading sensors. I'll dig a bit into it now.
content.html: ok I checked there's definitely a problem loading sensors. I'll dig a bit into it now.

content.raw: Maybe should add an expectation on `World::SensorsInitialized()`, and possibly call `SensorManager::SensorsInitialized()` too
content.html: Maybe should add an expectation on World::SensorsInitialized(), and possibly call SensorManager::SensorsInitialized() too

content.raw: Yeah that sounds good, I'll add it to the test. I believe I solved the problem and I'm writing a test now.
content.html: Yeah that sounds good, I'll add it to the test. I believe I solved the problem and I'm writing a test now.

content.raw:
So I spent a long time tracing things and trying to figure out why they fail sometimes, why they pass other times. And came to the conclusion that there are a lot of messages going back and forth and sometimes there isn't enough time for all of this to happen. So my solution for now was to add some long sleeps. Let me know if anyone can think of a better solution. I added some comments to the code too. 5eeab52

Oh, and even with all the sleeps, `PluginCount` and `World::SensorsInitialized` seem to fail sometimes.
content.html:
So I spent a long time tracing things and trying to figure out why they fail sometimes, why they pass other times. And came to the conclusion that there are a lot of messages going back and forth and sometimes there isn't enough time for all of this to happen. So my solution for now was to add some long sleeps. Let me know if anyone can think of a better solution. I added some comments to the code too. 5eeab52

Oh, and even with all the sleeps, PluginCount and World::SensorsInitialized seem to fail sometimes.

content.raw: One more question. What's the expected behavior when plugins are loaded and we open a new world? Unload them all as part of the teardown process of the old world?
content.html: One more question. What's the expected behavior when plugins are loaded and we open a new world? Unload them all as part of the teardown process of the old world?

content.raw: World plugins and model plugins should be unloaded the same way as when Gazebo is shutdown. I haven't looked much into system plugins. And GUI plugins are not important right now.
content.html: World plugins and model plugins should be unloaded the same way as when Gazebo is shutdown. I haven't looked much into system plugins. And GUI plugins are not important right now.
